discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C for sure... RAID 1 consumes 200% and RAID 5 133% and both protect against data loss and RAID 6 even more reliable
C for sure... RAID 1 consumes 50% and RAID 5 33% and both protect against data loss

comments.content: sorry i corrected all this in above comments

discussion.content:
C is right.

The space savings of erasure coding is guaranteed. For example, assigning a policy with a RAID-5 erasure coding rule reduces capacity consumption by 33 percent versus the same level of availability (FTT=1) with RAID-1 mirroring.

Taken from vSAN 6.7 Deploy and Manage Lecture Manual - Level of Failures to Tolerate section

questions.question_text: Which fault tolerance method protects business data and achieves storage space efficiency?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
https://www.vmware.com/content/dam/digitalmarketing/vmware/en/pdf/products/vsan/vmware-virtual-san-health-check-guide-6.1.pdf
page: 12.

"...The following set of new features and functionality are available in version 6.1.0 of 
the Virtual SAN Health Check:
• vCenter Events/Alarms support: If the plug-in detects any problem during 
health checks, events/alarms are surfaced. The backend health check runs 
periodically every 60 minutes by default. However the check interval is 
customizable through both vSphere UI and RVC
D for sure but can be changed to suit your needs

D is right.

Monitor the Health pane on a regular basis. Expand the test category to view the individual tests. Select a test to view detailed test results. You can click Retest to manually run all the tests. Otherwise, the tests are run every 60 minutes.

Taken from vSAN 6.7 Deploy and Manage Lecture Manual - vSAN Health Check Categories section

vSAN Health is enabled by default and configured to check the health of the vSAN environment every 60 minutes. The 60-minute time interval is the recommended setting, but this setting can be changed.
https://storagehub.vmware.com/t/vsan-6-7-update-1-technical-overview/vsan-health-check/

questions.question_text: What is the configured default time of vSAN Health?

A 100GB virtual disk object has this storage policy assigned to it:
✑ Site disaster tolerance: None "" standard cluster
✑ Failures To Tolerate: 1 failure "" RAID-1 (Mirroring)
✑ Number of disk stripes per object: 1
What is the maximum amount of raw vSAN storage capacity consumed by the virtual disk?

Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

A storage policy has been created for the 3-node vSAN cluster in the exhibit. A VM is deployed using this policy.
What is the expected behavior?

choices.B: VM will be deployed and is reported compliant.
choices.C: Force provisioning will be turned off automatically.
choices.A: VM will be deployed but remain non-compliant.

discussion.content: I agree with answer A, once force provision is enabled it will deploy the VM with non-compliant information

Selected Answer: A
For sure...one host in maintenance cause non compliance if 4th host was there then it is complaint based on the policy

A is the right answer but due to the maintenance mode of the third host. 
So is not possible to guarantee the FTT=1 when the cluster with 3 hosts has one node not operational and the VM policy will remain non-compliant.

questions.question_text: A 3-node vSAN cluster will take which two actions, when a drive is physically removed from a vSAN node? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Marks all components on that device as degraded
choices.A: Marks all components on that device as absent
choices.D: Marks all components on that device as stale
choices.C: Waits for the configured delay timer before rebuild

discussion.content:
A & C is correct. 

If a capacity device fails without an error, the cluster marks all components on that device as absent and waits the configured delay before beginning to rebuild the affected components.

Taken from vSAN 6.7 Deploy and Manage Lecture Manual - Failure Scenario: Rebuilding Components section
yes, as we pull off the disk, vsan don't marc object as inaccessible, it waits 60 minutes timer before begin the rebuild, if possible.
